intro: Porophyllum pausodynum, commonly known as the Mexican thistle, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of the southwestern United States. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and disturbed soils. Its foliage is generally gray-green with a fuzzy texture, and it produces small, white to pale pink flowers. Porophyllum pausodynum is often considered a weed due to its aggressive growth and ability to spread rapidly.
